newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - June 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - June 25.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

Australian Rugby League officials are confident of a future for State of Origin matches following strong ticket sales and an expected crowd of over 30,000 for tonight's final game in Sydney. Even though crowd figures were disappointing for the first two games, the series is expected to turn a good profit. Page 17

Super League club chief executives were informed during a telephone conference yesterday of the organisation's upper hand in continuing negotiations with the Australian Rugby League on the basis of recent developments in the pay TV industry favouring News Corporations' part-owned Foxtel pay TV operator. Page 17

Australian national netball team vice-captain Carissa Tombs wants to hold on to her position after she moves to England later this year. Tombs will return to play in the national netball league next year for selection in the Australian national team. Pae 17
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

A racial abuse allegation against Balmain hooker Darren Senter is now before the Australian Rugby League after a biting charge against Chargers second-rower Chris Nahi was cleared. Senter said there was a less than 50 per cent chance that he had been bitten, and Nahi claims the action was provoked by a racial slur. Page 48

Australia's Young Socceroos have defeated defending champions Argentina 4-3 at the World Youth (under-20) Championships in Kangar, Malaysia, with Kosta Salapasidis scoring all four goals. The team is now set to face Japan in a second-round meeting tomorrw night. Page 47

According to News Ltd sport director Ian Frykberg, Super League is set to push for the incorporation of a New Zealand team into next year's State of Origin series, should an agreement for a unified competition be reached. Page 48
THE AGE

North Melbourne Kangaroos' board has issued a one-match suspension to defender Mike Pike, and fined him an undisclosed amount, for bringing the club into disrepute. Pike has been charged by police for assaulting a woman in an Adelaide bar. Page B16

Gifted Geelong centre-man Paul Couch retired yesterday at age 32 after an illustrious sporting career in which he played 259 games, including 18 Finals and 4 Grand finals. Couch has suffered from cartilage damage in his left knee all during his career wih the Cats, and it is this injury that finally forced his retirement. Page B16

The Australian Football League's chief executive Wayne Jackson has announced the AFL may not provide direct financial compensation to Waverley Park co-tenants Hawthorn and St Kilda if they move to Docklands. Page B15
THE HERALD SUN

Two schoolboy teams from Syndal South Primary, Victoria, have beaten more than 200 competitors from across the State to win both gold and silver at the recent Image Sports school aerobics championships. The winning team will now travel to Brisbane to repesent their school and the State in the national finals. Page 72

Australian skier Kirstie Marshall, who holds the world record freestyle score of 197.92, was yesterday awarded the Vicsport Kitty McEwan Award for Sportswoman of the Year for her recent world championship performance in Japan. Marshall is currently in the US, training for the next World Cup. Page 77

Super League's Melbourne team is expected to be established by early November according to the club's new executive chairman, and former Super League chief executive, John Ribot. Ribot helped set up the Brisbane Broncos, and is now part-owner of the Melburne franchise. Page 77
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

A new Australian Rugby player transfer system, based on the New Zealand model, is expected to start in November, allowing any club wanting to sign on a wallaby player to do so for a fee of $100,000. Page 73

St George full back Dean Raper has been suspended for two matches following his use of abusive language to referee Paul Simpkins during a game against Illawarra at Kogarah Oval last Sunday. Raper has written an apology letter to Simpkins expressing his embarrassment over the incident. Page 77

Reds player Mark Geyer will soon end a 10-week suspension for eye-gouging Adelaide utility back Chris Quinn, following his selection by Reds' coach Dean Lance for the team's first grade run-on side match against Adelaide at the WACA. Page 76.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
